criteria.name: Ensure links are distinguished from surrounding text in a way that does not rely on color
criteria.remarks: Links must be distinguishable without relying on color [More info](https://dequeuniversity.com/rules/axe/4.10/link-in-text-block?application=axeAPI)

children.name: A Modern, highly responsive and accessible Design System

A collection of useful, internal tools for front-end development. It is intended to be used as a reference implementation for our design system and to help us build better, more accessible applications. In short, our Design System aims to achieve:
Built in Accessibility and a11y Protection
🙋 Have more questions? Is something not covered here? Post in the
Slack channel and someone from the Tastysoft team will be happy to help!

Cross-Framework Components are a new way to build components that can be used in multiple frameworks, such as React, Angular, Ruby and Vue. AKA "Framework Agnosticism" means it can be used anywhere. This allows developers to create components that can be shared across different applications, reducing the need to rewrite code for each framework. It also allows developers to decide on the best application framework for their needs, without being locked into a specific framework required by the Design System.

Both Parchment and Instructure ecosystems are growing rapidly, and we want to ensure that our Design System is flexible enough to support both. By using Cross-Framework Components, we can create a Design System that is not only modern and responsive, but also flexible and adaptable to the needs of our users.
Note: Be sure to check the repository for the latest release so that you avoid pulling in code changes that have not yet been validated by QA.

Note: Most of our applications set moduleResolution to 'node'. With modern applications that use 'bundler' this adjustment is not necessary. However, for full compatibility with our libraries, setting this to 'node' is recommended. If your application is set to 'node' and you are missing type declarations for the '/react' and '/server' entry points...
Implement ThemeProvider and Internationalization Support Globally
Implement ThemeProvider and Internationalization Support Globally
// (Optional) pass this to enable Contrast Theme
// (Optional) pass this to enable Dark Theme
TastySoft comes with a special entry point for Next.js app router implementations at

. This entry point ensures anything exported from this special path avoids export collisions with anything that requires client or context for a smoother Next.js experience. This implementation is required to create the best ThemeProvider user experience, which prevents screen flashing or shifting with each page load. This example implementation also covers a similar concept for Internationalisation, in the event a user chooses a different locale from the language selection component in the UI. With this setup, the page content will avoid flashing between languages with each page load.
Note: For SSR and app router implementations. Full example

schemas: [CUSTOM_ELEMENTS_SCHEMA] // Add this to allow custom elements

The React team worked towards full Custom Element (aka Web Component) support in React v19! This means our newer applications that can be easily uplifted can skip the /react entry point and just import and implement Cross-Framework Components directly from the main entry of the package.
